name.text: Simply supported beams. Finding reaction forces. Level 3

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 46 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two reaction forces, R1 and R2, one at either end of the beam. There is a distributed load of mass 5 kg from 21 cm to 31 cm.

By resolving forces and taking moments about A, determine the magnitude of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

Write your answer correct to 2 d.p.

R1 = {1:NUMERICAL:= 21.74:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N

R2 = {1:NUMERICAL:= 28.26:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N

generalfeedback.text:
Remember that when resolving forces, the sum of the upward forces must be equal to the sum of the downward forces.

For a system in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

Recall that when dealing with distributed loads, you can assume that the total force is acting at the midpoint of the load.

name.text: Simply supported beams. Finding reaction forces. Level 3

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 92 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two reaction forces, R1 and R2, one at either end of the beam. There is a distributed load of mass 10 kg from 28 cm to 58 cm.

By resolving forces and taking moments about A, determine the magnitude of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

Write your answer correct to 2 d.p.

R1 = {1:NUMERICAL:= 53.26:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N

For a system in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

Recall that when dealing with distributed loads, you can assume that the total force is acting at the midpoint of the load.

questiontext.text:

By resolving forces and taking moments about A, determine the magnitude of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

Write your answer correct to 2 d.p.

R1 = {1:NUMERICAL:=131.64:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N

R2 = {1:NUMERICAL:=128.36:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N
